sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: Protocol Form
sci:arg.sci:help: The path to a protocol that will render an HTML user interface for this protocol. This optional parameter is used by Web Port to provide a custom user interface for a protocol.

sci:arg.name: __PoolID
sci:arg.sci:help:
__PoolID is a case insensitive string that can optionally be set to optimize the speed of execution for quick running protocols. Multiple protocols with the same value for __PoolID can share expensive resources such as database connections, Java VMs, memory, etc. reducing the execution time by 1 to 2 seconds per run. This can give a large speed improvement to protocols that run in a few seconds such as web applications and interactive reports. Longer running protocols will not see much benefit. Generally, it is a good idea to use the same __PoolID for all protocols within a single application such as an interactive report since many of the components, databases, and data structures will be similar.

__PoolID can also be specified by the client when the protocol is launched. If __PoolID is specified both as a parameter by the client and as a parameter stored within the protocol, the client's value overrides the stored value.

To disable pooling entirely for this particular protocol, set __PoolID to <Disable>

sci:arg.name: Http Cookie Handling
sci:arg.sci:help:
Http Cookie Handling provides a mechanism to control the handling of Http cookies within components that access remote resources via Http and Https. These include the HTTP Connector, Data readers such as Text Reader, XML Reader (Generic), etc., and custom Java, Perl, and .Net components that use the available APIs for accessing remote servers. By default, New Protocols will have this setting enabled and set to "Protocol Scope". This means that Http cookies obtained from a remote server within any component in the protocol or any of its subprotocols will be parsed and appropriately sent back on subsequent requests from the same component or any other component. The handling of the cookies is based on the IETF standard as specified in http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6265. Setting the parameter to Disabled will prevent components from parsing and returning cookies to the remote servers.

Persistence of cookies is not supported, so scoping of Http cookies is entirely within the context of a single protocol execution.

Older protocols that do not have the Http Cookie Handling parameter will behave as though it had been set to "Disabled". To enable cookie handling in these protocols, copy this parameter from a New Protocol to the older protocol and set the parameter as desired.

sci:arg.name: __NotificationProtocol
sci:arg.sci:help:
__NotificationProtocol specifies the name or component ID (guid) of a protocol stored in the server's protocol database that will be executed when the current job completes. If your administrator has enabled notification protocols and depending on his or her preference, the notify protocol will either run as the anonymous user or as an admin specified user. The notification protocol receives several parameters that contain information about the original job:

  • Notify_JobID: The job id of the execution
  • Notify_JobStatus: A description of the result of the job execution
  • Notify_JobStatusCode: The status code that for the result of the job execution.
    • 5: Job was stopped by the client or administrator.
    • 6: Job completed normally with success.
    • 7: Job completed with an error.
    • 8: The process ID associated with the running job crashed or otherwise disappeared.
    • 9: Job failed to start.
  • Notify_ProtocolName: The name of the protocol
  • Notify_ProtocolPath: The path of the protocol in the DB. This field can be blank for protocols that were launched without saving to the database.
  • Notify_ProtocolLogName: The log name of the protocol. Is usually the same as ProtocolName, however this can be set by the client to a different name than the protocol.
  • Notify_RunHost: The name of the node where the protocol executed.
  • Notify_Username: The user that ran the job

sci:arg.sci:help: The maximum number of data records to read (all if value is empty)

sci:arg.name: SourceTag
sci:arg.sci:help:
The type of tag to create to identify the source of data records. A property called SourceTag is created and holds the value indicated.

  • None: No SourceTag property is created and any existing ones are removed.
  • Filename: The name of the file read.
  • FilenameAndExtension: The name of the file read with its file extension.
  • FullFilename: The name of the file read, including the directory path.
  • ZipFilename: When reading a compressed zip file, the filename within the compressed archive.
  • Number: When multiple files are read in this component, they are numbered 1,2,3...
  • Letter: When multiple files are read in this component, they are lettered A, B, C...
  • KeepCurrent: Keeps the current value of SourceTag.

sci:arg.name: Keep Properties
sci:arg.sci:help: A list of properties the reader should retain for each data record that is output. If a value is not defined, retains all properties. If the parameter contains the value "-" (minus sign), properties are not retained.

sci:arg.name: UTF-8 Auto Detect
sci:arg.sci:help:
UTF-8 is a type of character encoding used to represent international characters with multiple bytes whereas basic Latin characters remain as a single byte. Files can be stored with a Byte Order Mark (BOM) to indicate that the type of character encoding.

When reading files that do not have a BOM, this parameter allows the reader to attempt to automatically detect UTF-8 encodings and convert as needed. However, be aware that automatic detection is not always reliable. In some cases, valid text stored in different character encodings can appear to be valid UTF-8. In these cases, the automatic detection will result in garbled text. When this occurs, you can consider using the Binary Reader to read the file, then converting using the Pilotscript function ConvertBytesToString

sci:arg.name: Additional Options

sci:arg.name: SD Format Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
Options available for the SD Reader:

  • Properties Can Contain $$$$: By the CTFile standard, a property can contain a '$$$$'-line. Properties or data field values are terminated by a blank line. Only then will the '$$$$'-line terminate the full data block. Setting this option off will terminate the data block upon any read of a '$$$$'-line. This option is available to provide compatibility with some 3rd Party SD files.
  • One-space Lines Terminate Properties: By the CTFile standard, properties or data fields values are terminated by a blank line. Selecting this option will terminate the data block when encountering a line containing a space as the only character in the line. This option is available to provide compatibility with some 3rd Party SD files.
  • Unwrap Long Property Lines: By the CTFile standard, lines in property fields cannot exceed 200 characters. When this option is selected and a property line of exactly 200 characters is found, the newline character will be ignored and property string will continue on the next line.
  • Read Unknown Stereo Parity: When selected, the SD Reader will use the 'Atom Parity' value (parity of '3') to mark unknown stereo centers in 3D mol files. This will leave these atoms marked as 'unknown stereo' and will not calculate the stereo from the coordinates.
  • Process Complex Data Header Lines: Data header lines are the lines in the SD format that precede the actual data. They can contain the data field name (enclosed in angular brackets <>), the data field number (as DTn), the external registry number (enclosed in parentheses), and other optional information. When this parameter is set to False, only the data field name is parsed and used to set the corresponding property name. All the other information in the line is ignored. When the parameter is set to true, all the information is parsed. The property name is set from either the field name in <> or the DTn. If both are present the field name takes priority and the DTn number is saved as an additional property named FieldName#DTn. The external registry number is saved as FieldName#ExtRegNum and any other information is saved as FieldName#OtherDataFieldInfo. When the molecules are written to an SD file, the data header lines are reconstructed from these properties. The default state of this parameter is False, as parsing, preserving, and eventually writing all the information in the data header lines can be costly, specially for SD files with many data fields.
  • Convert From H2 And H+ Atom Types: 'H2' and 'H+' are two non-standard element types that can be assigned to atoms by the BIOVIA Draw sketcher. They represent unattached Hydrogen (a Hydrogen molecule) and charged Hydrogen (a proton), respectively. When this parameter is selected, these atom types are converted to standard hydrogen atoms upon reading, with charges of 0 for H2 and +1 for H+. Otherwise, these atoms are read and perceived as unknown atom types, with 'H2' and 'H+' as the atom labels.
  • Convert Radicals To Pi Systems: When selected, pi bonds will be perceived between adjacent atoms marked with radicals and any adjacent metal atom. Once pi bonds are perceived, subsequent exports will represent the pi bonds using the V3000 format and one-to-many coordination bonds (type 9) unless the writer's Convert Pi Systems To Radicals option is used to convert the pi systems back.
  • Convert GEN+DAT to Polymer Repeat Units: When selected, this option will automatically convert input GEN sgroups with linked DAT sgroups having the special fieldname of 'rc' and numeric or numeric range data internally into polymer repeat sgroups. This usage is a special type of NONS (Non-Specific Structure) convention that was prototyped in previous releases. Disabling this conversion will have a higher likelihood of producing a structure that can be registered into Direct databases.
sci:arg.sci:legalval: Convert From H2 And H+ Atom Types
Convert GEN+DAT to Polymer Repeat Units

sci:arg.name: TestForCore
sci:arg.sci:help: An expression applied to each data item that determines which ones are core structures

sci:arg.name: CoreMappingsAreDifferentWhen
sci:arg.sci:help:
Duplicate core mappings are discarded. Allows you to control what counts as different.
  • AtomSetIsDifferent: Different core mappings have different target atoms sets.
  • AtomMappingIsDifferent: Different mappings have different mappings from the query to the target.
  • RAttachmentMappingIsDifferent: The mapping of the core atoms attached to RAtoms is considered.

sci:arg.name: CoreNameFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: Name of the property that contains the name of the core structures

sci:arg.name: MappingOptions
sci:arg.sci:help:
This parameter contains options that control the mapping of the core onto the target molecules. (See also Search Options to control the behavior of the underlying substructure mapper.)

  • Annotate Core with New RAtoms: Whether to annotate the core by adding new RAtoms where attachments are found. When not selected, only preexisting RAtoms included in the core will be used.
  • Annotate Core with Stereo: Whether to annotate the core by adding stereo if all the examples have attachments of the same stereochemistry.
  • Include RAtoms in Unique Check: If selected, then mappings that differ only by the fragments mapped by the RAtoms are treated as different. For example, a core of R1-NH-R2 would generate two mappings when given N-methyl aniline as an example, and generate two sets of fragments: CH3-Z1 and Z2-Ph, and CH3-Z2 and Z1-Ph. If not selected, then only one mapping is returned.
  • Add Numbers to ZAtoms: Whether to add the RGroup number to each ZAtom that is created in the fragment.
  • Keep only Mappings with Maximum RAtoms Mapped: whether to optimize the acceptance of core mappings to only those that maximally assign RAtoms to non-hydrogen positions.
sci:arg.sci:legalval: Keep only Mappings with Maximum RAtoms Mapped

sci:arg.name: Search Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
Options for substructure searching. For maximum ISIS compatibility, select the first five options. Substructure Search options:
  • Use Localized Aromatic Bonds: "Localized" aromatic bonds are bonds for which all kekule representations have the bond always the same type (single or double). For example, the single and double bonds in pyrrole are localized, while the bonds in pyridine are not. ISIS allows single or double bond queries to map onto localized aromatic bonds. Setting this option will make this component compatible with ISIS with respect to these bonds. This replaces the old Use ISIS Aromaticity option.
  • Uncharged Atoms Can Map Charged Atoms: Allow uncharged query atoms to map onto charged target atoms.
  • NonChiral Queries are Enantiomers: Queries containing stereoatoms are considered as a mixture of enantiomers rather than absolute.

    For molecules with relative stereo groups (Accelrys Enhanced Stereo), this flag controls whether or not to check all the possible stereo configurations represented by the relative stereo groups when checking stereo. When the flag is OFF, only the actual stereo configurations present in the molecules (as drawn) are compared. When the flag is ON, all the possible combinations of stereo configurations for the query and the target are compared to look for a match.

  • Chiral Queries Only Map Chiral Targets: A query marked Chiral can map only onto targets marked Chiral.

    For molecules with relative stereo groups (Accelrys Enhanced Stereo), this flag controls whether or not check the types of stereo groups when checking stereo. When the flag is OFF, all stereo groups (ABS, OR, AND) are allowed to map each other. When the flag is ON, the matching rules for the relative stereo groups are:

    • ABS group in query can only map ABS group in target
    • OR groups in query can map OR and ABS groups in target
    • AND groups in query can map AND, OR, and ABS groups in target.
  • Stereo Atoms Can Map Nonstereo Atoms: Marked stereoatoms must map onto stereo-appropriate atoms in the targets, instead of being allowed to also map onto unknown or unmarked atoms.
  • HFill if RAtoms Found: If RAtoms are found in the query, hydrogen-fill all other atoms; allow substituents only in the locations marked by the RAtoms.
  • Check Bonds To RAtoms: Toggles the check of query features (e.g. order, Chain/Ring) on bonds to RAtoms. By default, this option is off to match ISIS behavior.
  • Interpret RAtoms Literally: Treat R atoms as literal atoms, rather than as query types. Useful for searching and manipulating literal RAtoms in target molecules.
  • Interpret ZAtoms Literally: Treat R atoms as literal atoms, rather than as attachment markers. Template (Z) atoms in queries are treated as A atoms attached by a bond which can be of any type (single, double, triple, or aromatic)
  • Interpret StarAtoms Literally: Treat Star (*) atoms as literal atoms, rather than as query features.
  • StarAtoms Can Map Hydrogens: Toggles whether Star (*) atoms can map hydrogen atoms.
  • Match Cis Trans Double Bonds: Toggles the checking of double-bond stereo. When this option is not checked, only the stereo for double bonds flagged with the stereo-care query feature will be checked.
  • Ignore Reaction Mappings: Toggles whether to ignore a reaction's atom-atom mappings and bond-status flags when matching against a reaction query. When checked, only a substructure match is performed.
  • Ignore Isotopes: Toggles whether to check isotope query features. Enabling this overrides other isotope options.
  • Marked Isotopes Only Map Marked Isotopes: When set, query atoms with isotopes marked will only map target atoms that have their isotopes marked. This is true even if the isotope marked matches natural abundance. That is, "16O" maps "16O" but not O.
  • Unmarked Isotopes Only Map Unmarked Isotopes: When set, query atoms with isotopes unmarked will only map target atoms that also have their isotopes unmarked. That is, "O" maps "O", but will not map either "16O" or "18O".
  • Exact Match: Return only targets that are an exact match to the query. That is, queries are required to match the entire target and not just a substructure of the target.
sci:arg.sci:legalval: Uncharged Atoms Can Map Charged Atoms
Chiral Queries Only Map Chiral Targets
Stereo Atoms Can Map Nonstereo Atoms
Marked Isotopes Only Map Marked Isotopes
Unmarked Isotopes Only Map Unmarked Isotopes

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Generates RGroup fragments given one or more core structures and target molecules to fragment

Takes as input one or more molecules tagged as cores, as specified by Test for Core, and target molecules, defined as any molecule not tagged as core. An R-group analysis using each core is conducted for each target molecule. The cores are mapped onto the target molecules generating fragments in which the attachment points are marked as template (Z) atoms. The R positions in the core are marked as R atoms.

Both the core structures and the generated fragments are passed through the Pass port. The original target molecules are discarded. Target molecules which are not mapped by any core are passed through the Fail port.

Properties are added to each molecular data record to identify the R positions in the cores and the attachment points in the fragments. These properties are named R1, R2, R3, etc. On the core molecule, the number in the R position property is the atom index of the core atom to which the R atom is attached. On the fragments, that number is the atom index of the Z-atom. An additional property, CoreId, is added to each fragment. This property specifies the name of the core molecule used to generate the fragment.

See also:

  • To enumerate molecules given a core with R positions and fragment molecules, use Enumerate using RGroups.
  • To read and write files with core and fragments, use RG Reader and RG Writer.
  • For an example of generating RGroups see 01 Generate Complex Fragments from Indole.
Core(s) and fragments with attachment points

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Applies a PilotScript expression to each data record

PilotScript is the native scripting language in Pipeline Pilot. It is based on PL/SQL and allows you to query or alter the properties on data records. For example, the expression:

A := 10;
creates a property named "A" and sets the value to "10".

For each incoming data record the PilotScript statements in Expression are evaluated.

Notes:

  • To initialize global variables such as counters, use Initial Expression.
  • To clean up global variables or calculate final results use Final Expression.
  • Parameters on Custom Manipulators do not become global variables that can be accessed via @ParameterName syntax. They must be accessed by using the Parameter('ParameterName') function or by using token substitution via $(ParameterName) syntax.

See Also:

  • For more information on PilotScript, see PilotScript Overview.
  • To use PilotScript to filter data records use Custom Filter (PilotScript).

Since there is no data available at initialization time, only expressions referencing local or global properties are allowed.

sci:arg.name: Final Expression

Since there is no data available at finalization time, only expressions referencing local or global properties are allowed.

sci:arg.name: Keep Calculated Properties

sci:arg.sci:value: Passes data records for which a PilotScript expression evaluates to True

For each incoming data record, the PilotScript statements in Expression are evaluated. If the last statement in the expression evaluates to True or non-zero, the record is sent out the Pass port. Otherwise it is sent out the Fail port.

Notes:

  • To initialize global variables such as counters, use Initial Expression.
  • To clean up global variables or calculate final results use Final Expression.
  • Parameters on Custom Manipulators do not become global variables that can be accessed via @ParameterName syntax. They must be accessed by using the Parameter('ParameterName') function or by using token substitution via $(ParameterName) syntax.
Data records for which the final expression in the PilotScript evaluates to True or non-zero
Data records for which the final expression in the PilotScript evaluates to False or zero

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Output
sci:arg.sci:help:
Select the type of output required: Smiles or Canonical Smiles

Output properties can be calculated "on demand" by simply using their names within a PilotScript expression or as the parameter value to many parameters that require a property name.

sci:arg.name: Non Aromatic Smiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specify whether or not to write the SMILES string in the standard form, with lowercase letters representing aromatic atoms, or in a 'Kekulized' form, with all uppercase letters and explicit double bonds.
Note that writing SMILES in kekulized form is only available for non-canonical SMILES.

sci:arg.name: Write Star For Special Atoms
sci:arg.sci:help: Toggles whether or not to export all non-periodic table atom types with a '*'. This affects atoms of type R, Z, A, Q, M or any non-standard atom type such as 'Mod', 'Pol' or 'Foo'. When special atoms are exported this way, the SMILES more strictly adheres to the Daylight standard. For backward compatibility with previous versions of Pipeline Pilot, this is set to false by default.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Creates a text property containing a SMILES representation of the molecule

SMILES is a terse textual representation of molecular data. Canonical SMILES is a form of SMILES that is independent of how the molecule is drawn and so can be used to compare whether two molecules are identical.

Either or both of the following two properties can be calculated:
  • SMILES is a non-canonical representation for the molecule. (This is very fast to calculate compared to Canonical_SMILES.)
  • Canonical_SMILES is the representation that can be compared for identicality.
Note:
  • The canonicalization algorithm is SciTegic's; while it is derived from the published Daylight algorithm, however, lack of complete documentation of their procedure means that it will not necessarily give identical results. Compare two SMILES for identity only when having both canonicalized by the same method.
  • Stereo markings are only added to the SMILES when stereo is explicitly set on a stereocenter. This is often not the case for 3D molecules where the stereo is implied from the coordinates of the attached atoms and not from explicit stereo markings. To add stereo markings from coordinates use the SetStereoFromCoordinates action in the Standardize Molecule component.
See Also:
  • You can convert a SMILES string into a molecule using Molecule from SMILES.
  • For an alternative way of generating a canonical string representation, see Molecule to InChI.
Molecular data records augmented with text properties containing either the SMILES and/or the canonical SMILES of the molecule

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.
sci:arg.sci:value: Components\Chemistry\Data Access and Manipulation\Converters\Molecule To Text\Molecule to SMILES

sci:arg.name: MergeUsing
sci:arg.sci:help:
Name of the property (or a comma-separated list of properties) that will be used to merge on. Data records having the same value for this property will be merged. This property must contain scalar (i.e., non-array) data.

If multiple properties are specified, the values must be the same for all of the properties (unless MergeUsingListType is set to UseFirstDefinedValue).

sci:arg.name: MergeUsingListType
sci:arg.sci:help:
How MergeUsing properties are interpreted when more than one property is listed:

  • UseFirstDefinedValue: Use only the first property in the list that has a defined value for a record as the merge key.
  • UseAllValues: Use the concatentation of values of all properties listed as the merge key.

sci:arg.name: MergePropertyType
sci:arg.sci:help:
The types of values found in the property specified by MergeUsing:

  • IsNumeric: All numbers are converted to doubles for comparison (e.g., 1 = 1.0).
  • IsText: All comparisons are made as string values.
  • IsDate: The key is considered a date.
  • IsFingerprint: The key is considered a fingerprint. Fingerprint bits are sorted before making the comparison.

sci:arg.name: IgnoreCase
sci:arg.sci:help: Considers lower-case and upper-case letters as equivalent when determining the identity of MergeUsing property values.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To enable, set MergePropertyType to IsText'); Parameter('MergePropertyType') eq 'IsText'

sci:arg.name: MergeBehavior
sci:arg.sci:help:
Controls how properties, other than the MergeUsing property, are handled.

  • KeepAll: Keeps all property values by appending values into an array.
  • KeepFirst: Keeps only the properties and values from the first example received. All properties and values from subsequent records matching the property specified by MergeUsing are discarded.

sci:arg.name: WhenMerging
sci:arg.sci:help:
When merging using KeepAll behavior, provides fine control over how multiple values are treated.

  • OverwriteOrCreate: Copies all properties of each merged record sequentially, overwriting any values that may already exist (instead of generating an array).
  • OverwriteExisting: Only copies properties that already exist on the first merged record, overwriting those original values (instead of creating an array).
  • CreateIfNew: Leaves any existing properties alone, and writes only new properties.
  • AppendOrCreate: Appends (as an array) if a property already exists, otherwise creates it.
  • AppendExisting: Appends (as an array) only to currently existing properties, and discards other new property values.

sci:arg.name: KeepAllNullString
sci:arg.sci:help: This string is used during append using KeepAll MergeBehavior to pad out empty values. It keeps the number of values of generated arrays of values the same, and in sync, for multiple samples. The default value is None, which causes no padding to occur.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To enable, set MergeBehavior to KeepAll'); Parameter('MergeBehavior') eq 'KeepAll'

sci:arg.name: KeepAllPreferredNodeName
sci:arg.sci:help: If defined, and MergeBehavior is KeepAll, this contains a name that is used to prioritize which underlying data record should be kept. If not defined, the first record with a given merge value is kept; if this is defined, and at least one of the data records contains a node of this type, then the first example of that type is kept.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To enable, set MergeBehavior to KeepAll'); Parameter('MergeBehavior') eq 'KeepAll'

sci:arg.name: PrefixUsingProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: When multiple values for a property are retained (under KeepAll merge behavior), the original property name is prefixed differently for each original value it must hold. The prefix is constructed from the value of this property, followed by an underscore. When not specified, a prefix is not used and multiple values are separated as an array (such as property[1], property[2], etc).

sci:arg.name: Data Are Sorted
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specifies whether the input data are already sorted by the MergeUsing properties. If so, then the merge can be done much faster with less memory impact. Use this option only if you are certain that the input data are sorted.

Note:

  • If you set Data Are Sorted to True and the input data are not sorted, an error is generated.

sci:arg.name: OutputFrequency
sci:arg.sci:help: Add a property called "Frequency" that contains the number of individual records included in the resulting merged record.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: AcceptNonNumericStringsAsNumbers
sci:arg.sci:help: Determines whether all string values for the MergeUsing property -- even non-numeric ones such as 'abc' or '1.0c' -- will be coerced to numbers when MergePropertyType is set to IsNumeric. If set to True, then a string such as 'abc' that does not begin with a numeric portion will be coerced to zero, while a string such as '1.0c' that begins with a numeric portion will be coerced to the corresponding number (in this case 1.0). If set to False, then records containing non-numeric strings for the MergeUsing property will be sent out the Fail port.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAutoDisplayName
sci:arg.sci:help: Automatically update the component display name when the "MergeUsing" property is changed. This feature is turned off after the user manually changes the display name of the component in Protocol workspace.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Merges properties of all data records that share the same key property value into a single data record

Incoming data records are merged into a single data record if they have the same value for the MergeUsing property, which acts as an ID or index property.

This component can be used to perform two types of operation:

  • Merge data records from multiple input streams. This combines properties from the multiple streams that are associated with the same index (i.e., MergeUsing) property. Typically this will widen the data records with more properties and reduce the total number of data records.
  • Merge data records from a single input stream to create array data. This maintains the number of properties but will reduce the number of records.
Note that these operations can occur simultaneously.

MergeBehavior controls how properties, other than the MergeUsing property, are handled.

Note:
  • Multiple MergeUsing properties can be specified. In this case, data records are merged if the value for each MergeUsing property matches across the data records.

See Also:

  • If you wish to merge records based on molecular structures, use Merge Molecules (which requires the Chemistry Collection).
Data records that contain the properties being used for merging
Data records that do not contain the properties being used for merging

sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ReplaceNullsInFirstRecord
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies whether to replace nulls in the first merged record when KeepAllNullString is specified.

sci:arg.name: Sort By
sci:arg.sci:help: Defines properties for sorting. Use this parameter to add, remove and reorder properties to be used for sorting.

sci:arg.name: Property 1
sci:arg.sci:help: The property to sort by.

sci:arg.name: Property 1 Sort Order
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether to sort in ascending or descending order.

sci:arg.name: Property 1 Sort As
sci:arg.sci:help:
Whether to sort as numbers, dates, or text.

Text can be case-sensitive or case-insensitive, and text containing numbers can be sorted based on the numbers (e.g., "test5" comes before "test23").

sci:arg.name: Property 2
sci:arg.sci:help: The property to sort by.

sci:arg.name: Property 2 Sort Order
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether to sort in ascending or descending order.

sci:arg.name: Property 2 Sort As
sci:arg.sci:help:
Whether to sort as numbers, dates, or text.

Text can be case-sensitive or case-insensitive, and text containing numbers can be sorted based on the numbers (e.g., "test5" comes before "test23").

sci:arg.name: Property 3
sci:arg.sci:help: The property to sort by.

sci:arg.name: Property 3 Sort Order
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether to sort in ascending or descending order.

sci:arg.name: Property 3 Sort As
sci:arg.sci:help:
Whether to sort as numbers, dates, or text.

Text can be case-sensitive or case-insensitive, and text containing numbers can be sorted based on the numbers (e.g., "test5" comes before "test23").

sci:arg.name: Maximum
sci:arg.sci:help: You can provide this to only return this number of records. This is useful when you only want to see the "best" record or records.

sci:arg.sci:help: When an expected data type is not found during processing: Halt: Terminate the execution of the network Fail: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Fail(red) port Pass: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Pass(green) port

sci:arg.name: ComponentAutoDisplayName
sci:arg.sci:help: Automatically update the component display name when the "Expression" property is changed. This feature is turned off after the user manually changes the display name of the component in Protocol workspace.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Sorts data records according to one or more properties

The incoming data records are re-ordered on output using the specified sort criteria. The sort criteria are defined by one or more properties whose values are used to order the records.

Use Sort By parameter to add more properties for sorting.

When multiple properties are used by sorting, the property values of Property 1 are checked first. If the values are equal, then the values specified by Property 2 are checked; if they are equal, then Property 3 is checked, and so on.

Notes:
  • The order of sorting can be changed using Sort Order.
  • The order of a set of records can be randomized by sorting on the property RandomNumber.
  • Records containing Null or undefined Sort By properties will be output to the Fail Port.
See Also:
  • Often, sorting of records is performed so that you can retain some number of records at the head of the sorted list. Top N Filter is the most efficient way to do this.
Data records that do not contain the sort field(s)

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Group By Property
sci:arg.sci:help: The property to be used to group each row of molecules

sci:arg.name: Maximum Number Of Groups
sci:arg.sci:help: A limit on the number of molecule groups to display

sci:arg.name: Groups Per Page
sci:arg.sci:help: The number of groups to appear on each HTML page.

sci:arg.name: Table Columns
sci:arg.sci:help: Number of columns to view per row

sci:arg.name: Title
sci:arg.sci:help: The optional title of the HTML document. This is shown in the browser's title bar when the document is opened.

sci:arg.name: Caption Property
sci:arg.sci:help: The property used to display a caption for the picture. If this parameter is not defined, a caption is not displayed.

sci:arg.name: Image Type
sci:arg.sci:help:
Format to use to represent the molecular image.
  • PNG: Portable Network Graphics.
  • JPEG: Joint Photographic Experts Group.
  • SVG: Scalable Vector Graphics.

sci:arg.name: ImageSize
sci:arg.sci:help: Size of the square image, in pixels
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Molecule Scaling') eq 'Fixed Image Size' or parameter('Molecule Scaling') eq 'Fixed Image Size with Fixed Bond Length'

sci:arg.name: Molecule Scaling
sci:arg.sci:help:
How to scale the molecule to the desired image size.
  • Fixed Image Size: the size of the images is the same for all the input molecules. The size of the image (in pixels) is controlled by ImageSize, which specifies the width and height. The aspect ratio is set to 1 by default, but can be modified by WidthToHeightRatio which sets the width as the height multiplied by the ratio. MaximumBondLengthSize can be used to define a maximum limit for the length of the lines used to draw the bonds (to prevent very small molecules such as ethane to be drawn disproportionally big).
  • Fixed Bond Length: all the molecules are drawn with the same bond length, specified by BondLengthSize. The image size depends on the size of the molecule. Small molecules create small images and big molecules create big images.
  • Fixed Image Size with Fixed Bond Length: the size of the images , specified by ImageSize, is the same for all the input molecules but, if possible, the molecules are drawn using the bond length specified by BondLengthSize. If the molecule can be drawn within the specified image size using the desired bond length, it is drawn like that, padding with white space as necessary. if the molecule is too big to be drawn with the desired bond length, it is scaled down to fit in the dimensions specified by image size.
sci:arg.sci:legalval: Fixed Image Size with Fixed Bond Length

sci:arg.name: MaximumBondLengthSize
sci:arg.sci:help:
Maximum size allowed for the lines used to draw the bonds in the molecule, in pixels. This parameter is used in conjunction with ImageSize to set a limit to how long the bonds in the molecule can be. This is useful to prevent small molecules, such as ethane, to be drawn disproportionally big.
Leave empty if you don't want to set a limit to the bond length.

sci:arg.name: MaximumImageSize
sci:arg.sci:help:
Maximum size allowed for the image, in pixels. This parameter is used in conjunction with BondLengthSize to set a limit to how big the image can be.
Leave empty if you don't want to set a limit to the image size.

sci:arg.name: BondLengthSize
sci:arg.sci:help:
Size of the average bond length, in pixels.

This parameter is used when Molecule Scaling is set to "Fixed Bond Length" or "Fixed Image Size with Fixed Bond Length".

The size of the image will not be constant. Bigger molecules generate larger images; smaller molecules generate smaller images.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Molecule Scaling') eq 'Fixed Bond Length' or parameter('Molecule Scaling') eq 'Fixed Image Size with Fixed Bond Length'

sci:arg.name: WidthToHeightRatio
sci:arg.sci:help: The ratio of the width to the height. When not equal to 1.0, the image height is given by ImageSize and the image width is scaled to fit the given WidthToHeightRatio.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Molecule Scaling') eq 'Fixed Image Size' or parameter('Molecule Scaling') eq 'Fixed Image Size with Fixed Bond Length'

sci:arg.name: Use Global Depiction Settings
sci:arg.sci:help: When set to True, the depiction options are set based on the settings specified by Global Depiction Settings and not from the component parameters.

sci:arg.name: Global Depiction Settings
sci:arg.sci:help:
Name of the XML file in the /apps/chemistry/xml/Objects folder with the global depiction settings.

The default XML file, with the same depiction settings as the default values of the component parameters, is PPDepictionSettings_Defaults.xml.

Use Export Depiction Parameters to modify and save depiction settings to use them as global settings.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter("Use Global Depiction Settings") eq true

sci:arg.name: Depiction Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Options that control the molecular depictions
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter("Use Global Depiction Settings") eq False

sci:arg.name: Atoms
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the drawing of atoms and atom labels

sci:arg.name: AtomLabelsScaleFactor
sci:arg.sci:help: Factor to scale the size of the atom labels (atom type, atom number, valence, value, charge). Set this factor to the default value of 1.0 to use the font size determined internally by PipelinePilot. Values greater than 1.0 will increase the font size. Values smaller than 1.0 will decrease the font size.

sci:arg.name: DisplayHighlightedAtomsAs
sci:arg.sci:help:
Select how to highlight selected atoms.
  • ColoredBlocks: Display a colored block superimposed on all the selected atoms.
  • ColoredLabels: Color all the selected atom labels with the same highlight color.

sci:arg.name: DrawImplicitHydrogens
sci:arg.sci:help:
Defines which implicit Hydrogen atoms to draw:
  • AllHydrogens: Displays all implicit Hydrogen atoms (this option overrides the other options).
  • HeteroHydrogens: Displays implicit Hydrogen atoms on heteroatoms.
  • TerminalCarbonHydrogens: Displays implicit Hydrogen atoms on terminal Carbon atoms.

sci:arg.name: AtomLabelPadding
sci:arg.sci:help: Padding size, in percentage of the average bond length, to use around atom type labels in the molecular image. This parameter controls how much white space to leave between atom type labels and the lines representing bonds.

sci:arg.name: Display Charge
sci:arg.sci:help: Specify whether or not to display non-zero atom charges

sci:arg.name: Display Valence
sci:arg.sci:help: Specify whether or not to display non-standard atom valences

sci:arg.name: Display Star Atoms As
sci:arg.sci:help:
How to display unknown star (*) atoms
  • As a star (*).
  • As a zigzag line.

sci:arg.name: Display 'Pol' Atoms As Circles
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether or not to display 'Pol' atom types as a circle. Whne set to False, these atoms are displayed using a 'Pol' label.

sci:arg.name: Display Hydrogen Isotopes as 2H and 3H
sci:arg.sci:help: When set to True, Hydrogen isotopes are displayed as '2H' and '3H' instead of 'D' and 'T'

sci:arg.name: Bonds
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the drawing of bonds and bond labels

sci:arg.name: DrawAromaticRings
sci:arg.sci:help:
How to draw aromatic rings.
  • UsingSingleDoubleBonds: A kekule representation using alternating single and double bonds.
  • AsSolidCircles: A solid circle is drawn inside the aromatic ring.

sci:arg.name: DisplayHighlightedBondsAs
sci:arg.sci:help:
Select how to highlight selected bonds.
  • ColoredLines: Color all the selected bonds with the specified highlight color.
  • ThickLines: Use a thicker line to draw the selected bonds.
  • ThickColoredLines: Use a thicker line and the highlight color to draw the selected bonds.

sci:arg.name: Draw Bond Query Labels
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether or not to draw labels indicating the bond query types (s/d, s/a, d/a, ...)

sci:arg.name: Position of Bond Labels
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the position of bond labels, such as query bond types (any, s/d, s/a, d/a), topologies (Ch, Rn), or bond numbers. The labels are placed either at one side of the bond or on top of the bond.
sci:arg.sci:legalval: At One Side of the Bond

sci:arg.name: Bond Thickness
sci:arg.sci:help: Specify the thickness of the lines used to represent bonds

sci:arg.name: Double Bond Width
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the witdh of double bonds, as a fraction of the bond length

sci:arg.name: Wedge Bond Width
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the witdh of stereo bond wedges, as a fraction of the bond length (including Either bonds)

sci:arg.name: Spacing of Down Bond Hashes
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the spacing between the lines of down bond wedges

sci:arg.name: DrawUnknownDoubleBonds
sci:arg.sci:help: How to draw double bonds with unknown stereochemistry (such as in molecules read from SMILES); either AsStandardDoubleBond or AsCrossedLines.
sci:arg.sci:member: Include Double Bonds in Small Rings

sci:arg.name: Include Double Bonds in Small Rings
sci:arg.sci:help: If False (the default), double bonds in small rings (size 7 or less) are never displayed as cross lines even if they are marked as unknown cis/trans stereo.

sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the selection of colors to draw the structures

sci:arg.name: UseColor
sci:arg.sci:help: If set to true, the molecular image will be colored according to atom types. If false, the image will be black and white only.

sci:arg.sci:help:
Specify the background color to use to draw the image.
Transparent should be set to 'False' for this parameter to be active.

sci:arg.sci:help: Specify the foreground color to use to draw the image.

sci:arg.name: Fonts
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the selection of fonts to draw the structures

sci:arg.name: TrueType Font File
sci:arg.sci:help: Path of the TrueType font to use to display the labels in the picture. Leave empty to use the default font.

sci:arg.name: SVG Font
sci:arg.sci:help:
Font family to use to draw text in SVG images.
Enter any valid SVG font-family specification.
Leave empty to use default font (Arial, Helvetica)

sci:arg.name: FixedFontSizeToDrawLabels
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specify a fixed font size to be used to draw the text labels in the molecular image. Text labels include atom labels (atom type, charge, isotope, implicit hydrogens, query features and custom labels and numbers), bond labels (query features, custom labels and numbers), molecule caption, chiral flag and custom labels.

If a fixed font size is specified, the labels are always drawn with the same size, irrespective of the molecule size.

Leave blank to scale the font size based on the size of the molecule.

sci:arg.name: MinimumFontSizeToDrawLabels
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specifies the minimum font size required to draw text labels for atoms, bonds and for the entire molecule (caption, chiral flag, etc). The font size used to draw these labels is calculated based on the size of the molecule. If it is smaller than the value of this parameter, labels are not drawn and heteroatoms are represented by circles with the color of the corresponding atom.

Leave blank to force the drawing of the text labels, even at very small font sizes.

sci:arg.name: Caption Font Size
sci:arg.sci:help:
Font size to use to draw the captions.

Leave blank to calculate the size automatically based on the image size and the length of the caption

sci:arg.name: Chemistry Labels Font
sci:arg.sci:help:
Font to use to draw the structure labels for atoms, bonds, abbreviations and Sgroup data.

Note:

  • On Windows systems, text labels are drawn differently for each of the fonts in the dropdown list. On Linux systems, the same font family is used for groups of fonts:
    • Arial
    • Bookman Old Style
    • Calibri, Cambria, Century Schoolbook, Garamond, Goudy Old Style, Lucida Console, MS Sans Serif, System, Tahoma, Verdana
    • Courier New
    • Times New Roman

sci:arg.name: Captions Font
sci:arg.sci:help:
Font to use to draw the caption label

Note:

  • On Windows systems, text labels are drawn differently for each of the fonts in the dropdown list. On Linux systems, the same font family is used for groups of fonts:
    • Arial
    • Bookman Old Style
    • Calibri, Cambria, Century Schoolbook, Garamond, Goudy Old Style, Lucida Console, MS Sans Serif, System, Tahoma, Verdana
    • Courier New
    • Times New Roman

sci:arg.name: Stereo Configuration Font
sci:arg.sci:help:
Font to use to draw the stereochemistry labels

Note:

  • On Windows systems, text labels are drawn differently for each of the fonts in the dropdown list. On Linux systems, the same font family is used for groups of fonts:
    • Arial
    • Bookman Old Style
    • Calibri, Cambria, Century Schoolbook, Garamond, Goudy Old Style, Lucida Console, MS Sans Serif, System, Tahoma, Verdana
    • Courier New
    • Times New Roman

sci:arg.name: Sequence Label Font
sci:arg.sci:help:
Font to use to draw the sequence labels

Note:

  • On Windows systems, text labels are drawn differently for each of the fonts in the dropdown list. On Linux systems, the same font family is used for groups of fonts:
    • Arial
    • Bookman Old Style
    • Calibri, Cambria, Century Schoolbook, Garamond, Goudy Old Style, Lucida Console, MS Sans Serif, System, Tahoma, Verdana
    • Courier New
    • Times New Roman

sci:arg.name: General
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control general image settings

sci:arg.name: Transparent
sci:arg.sci:help: If set to true, the image will be transparent. If false, the image will have a white background.

sci:arg.name: Antialiasing
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether or not to use antialiasing when drawing graphic objects in the molecular image

sci:arg.name: Haptic/Markush
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the drawing of Markush bonds and Pi systems

sci:arg.name: Haptic Bond Display
sci:arg.sci:help:
Type of line to use to display Pi systems
  • Solid line.
  • Dotted line.

sci:arg.name: Markush Attachment Point Shape
sci:arg.sci:help:
Type of symbol to use to display the atoms representing Markush attachment points
  • Circle
  • Square
  • Star (*)

sci:arg.name: Markush Color1
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the color to use for the atoms that would be attached to the first Markush bond (will cycle after the fourth Markush bond)

sci:arg.name: Markush Color2
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the color to use for the atoms that would be attached to the second Markush bond (will cycle after the fourth Markush bond)

sci:arg.name: Markush Color3
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the color to use for the atoms that would be attached to the third Markush bond (will cycle after the fourth Markush bond)

sci:arg.name: Markush Color4
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the color to use for the atoms that would be attached to the fourth Markush bond (will cycle after the fourth Markush bond)

sci:arg.name: Reactions
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the drawing of reactions

sci:arg.name: Display Atom-Atom Mapping
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies whether or not to display the atom-atom mappings when depicting reactions

sci:arg.name: Display Reacting Center Marks
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specifies how to display the reacting center marks of reactants and products when depicting reactions
  • Hash Marks (For Change)
  • Color (For Change)
  • Thicker (For Change)
  • All Marks
  • Off

sci:arg.name: Display Stereo Markers
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies whether or not to display the stereo inversion and/or retention marks when depicting reactions

sci:arg.name: Rgroups
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the drawing of Rgroups
sci:arg.sci:member: Maximum Number of Members to Display

sci:arg.name: Display Attachment Points As
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specifies how to display the attachment points in Rgroup fragments
  • Template (Z) Atoms
  • Arrow and Star (*)
  • Line and Zigzag line

sci:arg.name: Maximum Number of Members to Display
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies maximum number of Rgroup members to be defined. If the RG structure includes more members, it will simply display numbers of members.

sci:arg.name: Sequences
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the drawing of biological sequences

sci:arg.name: Show Sequence View
sci:arg.sci:help: Shows sequence structure in the sequence view

sci:arg.name: Show Expanded Sequence Structure
sci:arg.sci:help: If this setting is true, expanded sequence residue shows its explicit structure instead of label.

sci:arg.name: Chain Color - First
sci:arg.sci:help: Color of the chain in Sequence

sci:arg.name: Chain Color - Second
sci:arg.sci:help: Alternate color of the chain in Sequence

sci:arg.name: Chain Color - Other
sci:arg.sci:help: Color of other chain types like Signal Peptides in Sequence

sci:arg.name: Mutations Color
sci:arg.sci:help:
Color to use to draw mutated residues in the biopolymer sequence.
The color can be defined as a string with three comma-separated integers between 0 and 255 representing the RGB numbers (example: 200,0,0) or as one of the predefined color names (Red, Green, Blue, Yellow, Cyan, Magenta, Black).

sci:arg.name: Modifications Color
sci:arg.sci:help:
Color to use to draw modified residues in the biopolymer sequence.
The color can be defined as a string with three comma-separated integers between 0 and 255 representing the RGB numbers (example: 200,0,0) or as one of the predefined color names (Red, Green, Blue, Yellow, Cyan, Magenta, Black).

sci:arg.name: Crosslinks Color - Default
sci:arg.sci:help: Color of the crosslink in sequence

sci:arg.name: Crosslinks Color - Disulfide
sci:arg.sci:help:
Color of the disulfide bridges in the sequence
The color can be defined as a string with three comma-separated integers between 0 and 255 representing the RGB numbers (example: 200,0,0) or as one of the predefined color names (Red, Green, Blue, Yellow, Cyan, Magenta, Black).

sci:arg.name: Crosslinks Color - Lactam
sci:arg.sci:help: Color of the crosslink that forms lactam bridge in sequence

sci:arg.name: Crosslinks Color - Lactone
sci:arg.sci:help: Color of the crosslink that forms lactone bridge in sequence

sci:arg.name: Sequence Block Size
sci:arg.sci:help: If this value is greater than 0, sequence structure will be displayed as the sequence labels blocked in this size. '0' means no blocking.

sci:arg.name: Sequence Wrap Length
sci:arg.sci:help: If this value is greater than 0, the sequence wraps to the next line after this number of sequence labels. '0' means no wrapping.

sci:arg.name: Spacing between Sequence Labels
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies spacing between sequence labels.

sci:arg.name: Spacing between Sequence Blocks
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies spacing between sequence blocks.

sci:arg.name: Spacing between Sequence Lines
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies spacing between sequence lines.

sci:arg.name: Display Sequence Block Numbers
sci:arg.sci:help: If this setting is true and there is sequence block size set, colume number at the end of each block is displayed at the top of the sequence.

sci:arg.name: Display Sequence Line Numbers
sci:arg.sci:help: If this setting is true, multiple line Sequence is displayed with starting number at the beginning of each row of sequences.

sci:arg.name: Sgroups
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the drawing of Sgroups

sci:arg.name: DrawFunctionalGroups
sci:arg.sci:help:
Draw specific functional groups as text instead of the actual atoms and bonds.

  • The functional groups to draw are defined using substructure searching with queries contained in the directory specified by FunctionalGroupsQueries. The default location of the functional group queries is /data/Queries/FunctionalGroups.
  • Each functional group query mol file must define the text to be drawn, the text color, and the core atom that connects the functional group to the rest of the molecule. Only functional groups with a single core atom are allowed.

sci:arg.name: FunctionalGroupsQueries
sci:arg.sci:help: Location of the functional group queries.

sci:arg.name: Stereochemistry
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the drawing of stereochemistry labels
sci:arg.sci:member: Stereo Label for R at Absolute Centers
Stereo Label for R at AND Centers
Stereo Label for R at OR Centers
Stereo Label for S at Absolute Centers
Stereo Label for S at AND Centers
Stereo Label for S at OR Centers

sci:arg.name: Chirality Label Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specify the labels to use to identify the stereo configuration of the molecule. The chirality label is drawn at the top of the molecular image.
  • Pipeline Pilot Defaults
    • All marked centers in one AND Enantiomer group: '' (no label).
    • All marked centers in one absolute group: 'Chiral'.
    • All marked centers in one OR Enantiomer group: 'Chiral Unknown'.
    • Marked centers in more than one stereogroup type: 'Relative'.
  • Accelrys Draw Defaults
    • All marked centers in one AND Enantiomer group: 'AND Enantiomer'.
    • All marked centers in one absolute group: '' (no label).
    • All marked centers in one OR Enantiomer group: 'OR Enantiomer'.
    • Marked centers in more than one stereogroup type: 'Mixed'.
  • Custom Labels
    Comma-separated strings with the labels to use to identify the chiral state of molecule. Four strings should be defined, with labels corresponding to the chiral states described above for the Pipeline Pilot and Accelrys Draw defaults.

sci:arg.name: Chirality Labels
sci:arg.sci:help:
Comma-separated strings with the labels to use to identify the chiral state of molecule. Four strings should be defined, with labels corresponding to the following chiral states:
  • All marked centers in one AND Enantiomer group.
  • All marked centers in one absolute group.
  • All marked centers in one OR Enantiomer group.
  • Marked centers in more than one stereogroup type.

sci:arg.name: Color of Absolute Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the color in which the stereo bonds, the stereo group labels or both are displayed at absolute stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Color of AND Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the color in which the stereo bonds, the stereo group labels or both are displayed at AND stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Color of OR Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the color in which the stereo bonds, the stereo group labels or both are displayed at OR stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Display Labels for Stereogenic Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Specify whether or not to display labels for the stereogenic centers (Abs, AND, OR)

sci:arg.name: Display Labels for Absolute Centers
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specify whether or not to display labels for the absolute stereogenic centers (Abs).

This parameter controls the display of Abs labels only. Use Display Labels for Stereogenic Centers to control the display of all labels (Abs, AND, OR)

sci:arg.name: Color Stereogenic Centers
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specify how to color the stereogenic centers with the colors specified by Color of Absolute Centers, Color of AND Centers, Color of OR Centers
  • Labels Only: color only the atom labels (Abs, AND, OR)
  • Bonds Only: color only the stereo bonds
  • Labels and Bonds: color both atom labels and stereo bonds
  • No Color: don't color the stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Stereo Label for R at Absolute Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Label to use for R Chirality at absolute stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Stereo Label for R at AND Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Label to use for R Chirality at AND stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Stereo Label for R at OR Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Label to use for R Chirality at OR stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Stereo Label for S at Absolute Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Label to use for S Chirality at absolute stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Stereo Label for S at AND Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Label to use for S Chirality at AND stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Stereo Label for S at OR Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Label to use for S Chirality at OR stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Zero Order Bonds
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the drawing of zero-order bonds (hydrogen and dative bonds)

sci:arg.name: Hydrogen Bonds Color
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the color to use to draw the lines that represent Hydrogen bonds

sci:arg.name: Dative Bonds Color
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the color to use to draw the lines that represent Dative bonds

sci:arg.name: Output Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
Settings controlling the viewer's output. Options are:
  • Display in Browser: Launch a separate browser window displaying the grouped compounds.
  • Output Reporting Element: Send a Pipeline Pilot Reporting element out the Pass port. This allows the output to be embedded within a larger report.

sci:arg.name: Use Default Browser
sci:arg.sci:help:
This parameter is only relevant when running the protocol in the Pipeline Pilot Professional Client.

The value specifies whether to use your default desktop web browser to view the HTML table. When set to False, Internet Explorer is used as a standard fallback option. If IE is your default browser, it is used in either case.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('Include a web browser as an Output Option to enable this parameter'); contains(Parameter('Output Options'), 'Display in Browser');

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help: Temporary file declarations

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help: Properties scoped to the subprotocol

sci:arg.name: Internet Explorer
sci:arg.sci:help: The location for Internet Explorer

sci:arg.name: Chrome
sci:arg.sci:help: The location for Chrome

sci:arg.name: Firefox
sci:arg.sci:help: The location for Firefox

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: Calculate 2DCoords For Expanded Residues
sci:arg.sci:help:
Ignore the existing coordinates of expanded residues in the structure and recalculate them before displaying the expanded residues connected to the sequence.

The 2D Coords calculation uses the Accord algorithm with backbone templates for amino acids and nucleic acids to try to align them nicely with the sequence.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter("Show Sequence View") eq true and parameter("Show Expanded Sequence Structure") eq true

sci:arg.name: Only Residues With Expanded SUP
sci:arg.sci:help:
Show only expanded residues when the Superatom abbreviations (SUP Sgroups) that represent them have the expanded flag On.

For SCSR sequences created by BIOVIA Draw, modified residues and residues connected by bridges are represented by explicit atoms with SUP Sgroups, but the expanded flag is not set to On unless the user expands them explicitely.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter("Show Sequence View") eq true and parameter("Show Expanded Sequence Structure") eq true

sci:arg.name: ProtocolAutoLayout
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol AutoLayout

sci:arg.name: AutoLayout
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol AutoLayout

sci:arg.name: ProtocolScale
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Scale

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Generates and displays an HTML page of molecules grouped by the value of a given property

Molecules with the same Group By Property property are displayed together. Molecular images are tiled beneath a header containing the value of the Group By Property property. Other properties are not displayed. The Caption Property parameter is available for annotating the images.

See Also:

  • A special instance of this viewer for displaying clusters is the HTML Molecular Cluster Viewer.
  • For and ungrouped HTML page that also contains properties, see HTML Molecular Table Viewer.
Molecular data records to be displayed in groups
A reporting element containing the grouped compounds if the "Output Reporting Element" option is selected
Data records missing the Group By Property or over the Maximum Number of Groups limit

sci:arg.name: Protocol Sticky Notes
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Sticky Notes

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ProtocolScale2
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Scale

sci:arg.name: Protocol Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Options

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: SelectedAtomsProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: The property name of a property containing a list of atom IDs to highlight in the image

sci:arg.name: SelectedBondsProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: The property name of a property containing a list of bond IDs to highlight in the image

sci:arg.name: HighlightColor
sci:arg.sci:help: The highlight color for selected atoms or bonds

sci:arg.name: ComponentRevision
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Revision

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: ByReference
sci:arg.sci:help: By Ref

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: Graphics Library
sci:arg.sci:help: Graphics library to use to render the structures

sci:arg.name: SubProtocolMadeLinkIntoCopy
sci:arg.sci:help: Subprotocol Made Link Into Copy

sci:arg.name: SubProtocolModified
sci:arg.sci:help: Subprotocol Modified

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.
sci:arg.sci:value: Components\Chemistry\Data Access and Manipulation\Viewers\HTML Molecular Grouped Viewer

sci:arg.name: Source
sci:arg.sci:help:
The file(s) or URL source(s) to read.

This may be a comma-delimited list of files or URLs. URLs may include http, https and ftp. Simple wildcard tokens are supported (* and ?).
sci:arg.sci:value: E:\课题研究\天然产物课题研究\2-不同生物来源天然产物的化学信息学分析\3-天然产物课题总结\3-补充\多酚类化合物糖基取代位点\Flavonoids Glycosides\Glycoside\Flavones and Flavonols.csv

sci:arg.name: Maximum
sci:arg.sci:help: The maximum number of data records to read (all records if value is empty).

sci:arg.name: SourceTag
sci:arg.sci:help:
The type of tag to create to identify the source of data records. A property called "SourceTag" is created and holds the value indicated.

  • None: No SourceTag property is created and any existing ones are removed.
  • Filename: The name of the file read.
  • FilenameAndExtension: The name of the file read with its file extension.
  • FullFilename: The name of the file read, including the directory path.
  • Number: When multiple files are read in this component, they are numbered 1,2,3...
  • Letter: When multiple files are read in this component, they are lettered A, B, C...

sci:arg.name: Keep Properties
sci:arg.sci:help: A list of properties the reader should retain for each data record that is output. If a value is not defined, the reader retains all properties. If the parameter contains the value "-" (minus sign), no properties are retained.

sci:arg.name: HasColumnNames
sci:arg.sci:help: When True, property names are taken from the first line of data in the file. When False, properties are named Column1, Column2, etc.

sci:arg.name: Sheets
sci:arg.sci:help:
Identifies the Excel worksheets within the specified file to read.

  • AllSheets: Read all worksheets sequentially.
  • ActiveSheet: Read only the active worksheet when opened by Excel. (The active sheet is the sheet on top when the file was saved.)
  • SheetName: Read only the worksheet named by the SheetName parameter.

sci:arg.name: SheetName
sci:arg.sci:help: This parameter is only relevant if Sheet is set to "SheetName". In this case, use this parameter to specify which sheet is to be read.

sci:arg.name: SheetTag
sci:arg.sci:help:
If set, a new property named "SheetTag" is defined on each generated data record. This property indicates the worksheet from which the data is read.

  • None: No SheetTag property is created.
  • SheetName: The name of the worksheet from which the data record is read.
  • SheetNumber: When multiple worksheets are read in from one file, they are numbered 1,2,3...

sci:arg.name: Additional Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Contains less commonly used parameters

sci:arg.name: CommentLines
sci:arg.sci:help: A comma-separated list of rows and row ranges to specify which initial rows in each Excel worksheet should be ignored by the parser (column headers will be read from the next row).

sci:arg.name: UndefinedString
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the character or string used to represent an undefined string in the file being read. When a cell value is encountered containing the undefined string, the property is omitted from the output data record.

sci:arg.name: AllLines
sci:arg.sci:help: When True, all lines of the text file become part of a single data record. The values for a column from each row become multiple [array] values for the property (column).

sci:arg.name: TrimWhitespace
sci:arg.sci:help: Trims whitespace from the left and right ends of each value.

sci:arg.name: DateFormat
sci:arg.sci:help: Determines the way in which date values are assigned to generated data records. Choose the "Text" option to format Excel date cell values as text strings. The "DateTime" option will result in SciTegic DateTime data properties on the data record.

sci:arg.name: PreserveExcelFormats
sci:arg.sci:help: Determines if formatting of the data is preserved. Choose the "True" option to preserve the Excel formats and mimic the behavior of Excel(on server) component. This value is set to "False" by default. Default behavior is to use the original non-formatted numeric cell values to generate properties. Note that if the value is "True", all values will be converted to strings in order to preserve the formatting.

sci:arg.name: Reduced Memory Usage
sci:arg.sci:help:
When set to True and the Shortcut Version of Implementation parameter is greater than 1, this component will use much less memory than the previous version with some limitations (See "Known Limitations" below). When you encounter the issues with this mode, turn this parameter off to work around these limitations.


Notes:
  • When the value is set to False, old version's behavior is maintained.
  • When the source file's format is Excel .XLS format (Excel '97-2003), this parameter is ignored. This parameter is only applicable to Excel 2007 .XLSX and .XLSM files.
  • When the Shortcut Version is absent or less than 2, this parameter is ignored. In this case, old version's behavior is maintained.

Known Limitations:
We are aware of the following limitations when using this parameter.
  • Source files should be saved with Microsoft Excel. Files generated by 3rd party programs may not work with this parameter.
  • Excel formula support is very limited. Files that contain Excel formulas may not work with this parameter.

sci:arg.name: Extract Comments
sci:arg.sci:help: Extract comments from Excel cells and add them to the property with the "SCI_Comment" metadata.

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help:
Lists a set of properties (without the @) to create on the global property list for this subprotocol. Such properties can only be accessed within the scope of this subprotocol and its descendent subprotocols.

Any global property not declared in this way is created on the top level global property list and is accessible from all protocols, but may collide with another property of the same name.

Scoping global properties to the subprotocol where they are used is highly recommended.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Read data from Excel files on Windows or Linux platforms.

Reads the Excel file or files specified by Source, creating one record for each row in each worksheet in each file. In addition to multiple comma-delimited files, there is support for simple wild cards (* and ?), and support for remote URLs (e.g. http).

This component reads both the older binary Excel .XLS format (Excel '97-2003) and the newer Excel 2007 .XLSX format.

This component can also read macro-enabled workbooks with the .XLSM extension, but macros are not evaluated.

The component does not require Excel to be installed on the server machine, and therefore is operational on Linux and Windows platforms

If HasColumnNames is True, the values on the first line of the file are treated as the property names. Otherwise, Column1, Column2, etc. are used as the property names.

Use Sheets and SheetName to include specific worksheets within the files. Individual rows and ranges of rows can be excluded using CommentLines.
One record per row in the Excel spreadsheet(s).

sci:component.name: SMILES and InChI Name to Structure

sci:arg.name: Chem Name Property
sci:arg.sci:help: The name of the property holding the chemical name to be converted.

sci:arg.name: String Representation of Structure to Output
sci:arg.sci:help:
A string representation of the structure resulting from the name conversion. The representation is included on the output data record.

If the input to this component is a single chemical name, then the output data record will represent the molecule directly. With this parameter, you may also choose to represent the structure as a string on the output (as either a CTAB, Smiles, or Canonical Smiles string).

When the input to this component is a list of names (i.e., an array of name strings), then the output data record cannot represent all the result molecules directly. In this case, the structures are represented solely based on your choice here. The output will also be an array, one element for each name. Array inputs are common when processing document data records, where more than one name was found in the document.

The structure will be output in a property named ChemCTAB, ChemSmiles, or ChemCanonicalSmiles respectively. If the input is an array of names, then if a given chemical name did not convert, the corresponding output value in the array is No Structure.

sci:arg.name: Molecule Custom Filter
sci:arg.sci:help:
A PilotScript expression to filter which structures should be retained in the output.

For example, names of very small structures (such as "water") are common in documents. To filter out these common small structures, use a PilotScript expression such as:

  • Molecular_Weight >= 20
Molecules not meeting the expression constraint are treated the same as names that could not be converted (i.e., they are output on the fail port or labelled as "No Structure", depending on the Document Processing Options).

Other useful expressions might be:

  • Num_Atoms > 5
  • ALogP > 1

sci:arg.name: Document Processing Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Options for processing documents, or other data records that have multiple ChemNames represented as an array

sci:arg.name: Keep Best Name Variations
sci:arg.sci:help:
If true, keep only the best (longest) name variations for each segment of text. If false, keep all variations.

Note: When the input data record has a single chemical name, converted names are output on the Pass port and unconverted names are output on the Fail port. However, when the input is an ARRAY of chemical names, then parameters Keep Best Name Variations and Keep Unconverted Names combine to determine whether each chemical name is retained in the output or is discarded. The behavior is depicted in this table:
Parameters ... ChemName is ...
Keep Best Name VariationKeep Unconverted Names Converted, is BestConverted, not Best Not converted, is BestNot converted, not Best
TrueTrueKeepDiscardKeepDiscard
TrueFalseKeepDiscardDiscardDiscard
FalseTrueKeepKeepKeepKeep
FalseFalseKeepKeepDiscardDiscard
The four possible parameter settings are given in the first two columns. The kind of name, and its disposition in the output, are given by the last four columns. For example, when both parameters are True, then the best converted name or the best unconverted name are retained, but other names are discarded. "Best" is relative to any span of text where more than one name has been identified. If more than one name is found in a span of text, then the best name is the longest converted name; if no names convert, then "best" is the longest unconverted name.

sci:arg.name: Keep Unconverted Names
sci:arg.sci:help:
If true, the array of ChemNames remains the same, regardless of which names were converted. If false, the array of ChemNames includes only those names that could be converted.

Note: When the input data record has a single chemical name, converted names are output on the Pass port and unconverted names are output on the Fail port. However, when the input is an ARRAY of chemical names, then parameters Keep Best Name Variations and Keep Unconverted Names combine to determine whether each chemical name is retained in the output or is discarded. The behavior is depicted in this table:
Parameters ... ChemName is ...
Keep Best Name VariationKeep Unconverted Names Converted, is BestConverted, not Best Not converted, is BestNot converted, not Best
TrueTrueKeepDiscardKeepDiscard
TrueFalseKeepDiscardDiscardDiscard
FalseTrueKeepKeepKeepKeep
FalseFalseKeepKeepDiscardDiscard
The four possible parameter settings are given in the first two columns. The kind of name, and its disposition in the output, are given by the last four columns. For example, when both parameters are True, then the best converted name or the best unconverted name are retained, but other names are discarded. "Best" is relative to any span of text where more than one name has been identified. If more than one name is found in a span of text, then the best name is the longest converted name; if no names convert, then "best" is the longest unconverted name.

sci:arg.name: Expression
sci:arg.sci:help: Expression (or list of expressions separated by semi-colons) to evaluate.

sci:arg.name: Initial Expression
sci:arg.sci:help:
This expression is executed only the first time data passes into the component.

Since there is no data available at initialization time, only expressions referencing local or global properties are allowed.

sci:arg.name: Final Expression
sci:arg.sci:help:
This expression is executed only at finalization (after the last data passes out of the component).

Since there is no data available at finalization time, only expressions referencing local or global properties are allowed.

sci:arg.sci:help: When an expected data type is not found during processing: Halt: Terminate the execution of the network Fail: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Fail(red) port Pass: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Pass(green) port

sci:arg.name: OnGeneralError

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Applies a PilotScript expression to each data record

PilotScript is the native scripting language in Pipeline Pilot. It is based on PL/SQL and allows you to query or alter the properties on data records. For example, the expression:

A := 10;
creates a property named "A" and sets the value to "10".

For each incoming data record the PilotScript statements in Expression are evaluated.

Notes:

  • To initialize global variables such as counters, use Initial Expression.
  • To clean up global variables or calculate final results use Final Expression.
  • Parameters on Custom Manipulators do not become global variables that can be accessed via @ParameterName syntax. They must be accessed by using the Parameter('ParameterName') function or by using token substitution via $(ParameterName) syntax.

See Also:

  • For more information on PilotScript, see PilotScript Overview.
  • To use PilotScript to filter data records use Custom Filter (PilotScript).

sci:arg.name: Freeze Table Header
sci:arg.sci:help:
When set to True, this table's header and title will remain visible when the table is scrolled vertically.

Notes:

  • This feature only applies to HTML reports.
  • The fixed header behavior depends on what container (e.g., plain browser window, Tile component, Dynamic Content Container) that the Table is piped into.
  • To create a table of fixed pixel height, set this parameter to True and pipe this table into a Dynamic Content Container of fixed (i.e., non-percentage) height.

sci:arg.name: Use Default Browser
sci:arg.sci:help:
This parameter is only relevant when running the protocol in the Pipeline Pilot Professional Client.

The value specifies whether to use your default desktop web browser to view the HTML table. When set to False, Internet Explorer is used as a standard fallback option. If IE is your default browser, it is used in either case.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Displays data records as HTML in a web browser

Generates and displays an HTML table page of data records, with one record per row. Each property becomes a column in the table and each value a cell.

Notes:

  • Molecules will be displayed if present.
  • For hierarchical data records, only top level properties are displayed.
  • Any grouped data is displayed in nested tables.
See Also:
  • If you prefer not to view the grouped data, use Delete Children.
  • For more control over the display of molecules, use HTML Molecular Table Viewer.
